content:
are you perhaps holding shift while deleting. That is designed to bypass the deleted/ trash folder

That is Delete placed the deleted item into whatever folder you have in your account settings. Shift delete bypassed the folder and just removes the mail.

Next Do you have a deleted / trash folder with the trash can icon. I have been seeing a number of folk where there flags than make folders special have been lost and need to be restated, so in the case of trash, your account has no trash folder unless it has the trash icon.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
losing it where? Generally the correspondent field is an artificial construct and for incoming mail is populated using the information in the from: header. If the mail had no From: then there is nothing to copy to the correspondents.

While it is usual to have a From: it is not compulsory. It might also be a big part of why that particular mail made it to a spam or junk folder because if it odd in it's formatting.

content:
I have a sneaking feeling that the issue will be the the user agent: header as that has been changed to offer less information between V102 and 115.

Use the config editor to change the setting in 115 to mailnews.headers.useMinimalUserAgent to false

The bug report the change was implemented on https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1114475 and the somewhat sneaky way of changing the default in another bug when no one was looking. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1809356 so the change was force fed to everyone, not just those that cared.

Can you please report your results back here
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
THis is how I would do it. - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to profile folder. Click 'open folder' - exit TB - the account, if POP, is in the Mail folder, otherwise the Imapfolder. - it will appear as Mail\<accountname> with message folders such as inbox, inbox.msf, etc. - COPY the entire <accountname> folder and store on the external drive. - restart Thunderbird - click 'account settings' and then 'server settings' - note the bottom line links to 'local directory'. click the browse button to locate and select the folder you created on external drive. This may require a restart of Thunderbird - restart Thunderbird and all should be okay. Nothing will have been lost in the process. You can now delete that folder on drive c that you originally used as it isn't used anymore.

Reminder: when doing backups, you need to backup both your thunderbird profile and also the external drive folder.
creator: davidsk

content:
I've been looking into this for you since you mentioned the issue in a previous question. I've now found out where you set it, but only you can really know what you need to set.

  • Settings > General
  • scroll to bottom
  • click on 'Config Editor' button
  • In search type: zoom
  • look for : toolkit.zoomManager.zoomValues
  • By default it has these values: .3,.5,.67,.8,.9,1,1.1,1.2,1.33,1.5,1.7,2,2.4,3,4,5

The numbers I've made bold are the ones that used when you use Ctrl++ or 'Zoom' > 'Zoom In' So when you use Ctrl++, you can click on it up to 10 times - increments using 10 stages because there are 10 higher number options. The number 1 is the default reset zoom setting starting point.

  • To Edit click on the pencil icon button

This allows to manually alter the numbers. I tried the following: .3,.5,.67,.8,.9,1,2.5,5,7 After the number 1, I only entered 3 numbers: 2.5 and 5 and 7 Note: use a comma to separate numbers. This had the following effect. When I now use Ctrl++, it increments to a larger zoom quicker and I can only use the Ctrl++ a total of 3 times because there are only 3 numbers after the number 1. Basically less clicking/pressing of keys. There is less choice in the number of variable zoom levels. But if you find yourself doing a lot in Ctrl++ to get to a size you want then this fix will help a lot.

It means you need to consider what numbers you need after the number 1 As this is a personal adjustment setting, you may need to fiddle about with the numbers until you get what you prefer.

  • To save your choices click on the tick icon.

If you ever need to reset back to the default set of numbers then you can click on the far right curved anti-clockwise arrow.

Remember - Before you test your settings Reset everything back to default: View > Zoom > Reset Zoom and you may discover you need to reselect email as well.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The default setting for all font size in Message Pane is done in 'Settings' > 'General' which I answered in the other question you asked. I advised choosing a suitable size if you need to see a larger size font on all occasions - aka currently you have to zoom for every email.

I had no idea what settings you were using so I suggested:

  • Fonts for Latin and Other Writing Systems
  • Set 'Proportional Size' to eg: 18
  • Set 'Monospace Size' to 18
  • Set minimum size to 16 (allows a bit smaller but stops smaller font size)

But you felt this was too large.

So if you want the default setting to increase but the above settings were too much then try a bit less:

  • Fonts for Latin and Other Writing Systems
  • Set 'Proportional Size' to eg: 14
  • Set 'Monospace Size' to 14
  • Set minimum size to 12 (allows a bit smaller but stops smaller font size)

But 'zoom' itself is entirely different. It is a manual setting on a per email basis which is initiated only when you select it. If you find you sometimes use zoom, but not always then the method mentioned above means you can preset the zoom levels meaning you don't need to keep clicking to get a suitable level.

But the zoom level number 1 means using default starting point to be whatever you set up in 'Settings' > 'General' > 'Language & Appearance' section > 'Advanced'

content: I presume you are referring to a csv file. I also presume that you can create the csv file from whatever is the source, something other than TB. The safest way I have found is this: - add at least one email address manually to the TB addressbook - then, highlight the addressbook, click the three dots to the right, download a csv file. - this is now your master template. open it in a spreadsheet program, alongside an opened csv file from elsewhere. rearrange the columns to match the layout (and first line) that you see in the TB's csv file. - save as csv - you now have a csv file that is perfectly aligned for importing to TB.
creator: davidsk

content:
No further responses to this I see. Am I the only one experiencing the issue? None of the last few updates have resolved it, but I have done a bit of snooping myself.

Essentially in my case when I run Thunderbird there are two instances of the Thunderbird .exe running and active under Apps (viewed using Task Manager). When I close Thunderbird those exact same two instance move down to Background Processes - and remain there.

If I do nothing, trying to restart Thunderbird will just spin the Windows icon (that indicates a background task) round and round but nothing will even happen. I've waited up to a half hour, but it never restarts - unless I first use TM to kill the two background processes. After that it will start as normal.

Similarly, with the latest update I clicked the Restart to Update Thunderbird button (which apparently uses a different shutdown process), went to take a shower, got dressed and came back and it was still hung and had not fully shut down. There are NO crashes in the crash log from this - it just hangs indefinitely, not registering as a crash.

I twiddled some settings, including "Use background process to update" but none of these made any difference. If I could export all settings and config I would be willing to uninstall and reinstall (I have numerous accounts in use).
creator: craigslistforsale01

content: First, I have no solution. BUT, I have a guess that the compacting is being interrupted. Look in windows file explorer (assuming you use windows) within the profile to see if there are any files with 'nstmp' in name. If so, those would be partially compacted folders, all of which may be deleted - and would be indicative of the interruptions. And also the frequent attempts to compact. Second, you might revisit your settings for compacting and adjust the size at which you want the compacting to occur. The interruptions might be due to an antivirus program or firewall... but that's beyond my knowledge. Anyway, maybe there's something useful here.
creator: davidsk

content:

That seems a bit high but I am limited as to what else to do.

I will see how it goes.

Thanks again!!

Les

content:
"too frequent" compacting is a known bug, with currently no known cure.

However, compact is being rewritten for version 128. If you continue to see problems in version 128 which comes out this summer, please be sure to post a new support item.

content: I have a PC with Thunderbird with one Account Name(AN) attached to a Hosted Email Provider(HEP) with my own DNS. I am changing the HEP. I plan to keep my current email name. I had hoped to simply modify the SMTP address information. I have been told this is not possible, that I have to create another AN and copy over my existing file folders. That is where the two questions above come in to play. Although I do not have the SMTP info from the new HEP I went ahead and added the new AN. I was expecting to see the first 6 folders of my current AN but instead there are just the Inbox and Trash. Is that to be expected or have I missed something? The second question relates to getting my original folders over to the new AN. I discovered the right click option mentioned above. I am wondering if that would be a good way to do the copying as opposed to doing it from a backup. It would seem to be a cleaner way to go. I hope this helps.
creator: dobrphi

content: All I can share is my personal experience. Whenever I set up a new account, I sometimes see just inbox and trash, and other folders appear as I use them, such as the sent folder. If this is a POP account, I would create the new account and exit TB without retrieving messages. Then use windows file explorer to copy the Mail\<accountname>folders to new account folder to ensure contiguous support for the messages.

content:
Some possibilities would be such as: - do they both communicate with internet identically, such as through the same router? - do they have different antivirus products? the same addons?

I am not an network guru, but those are the kinds of interferences that can cause messages not to be received. Thunderbird is only a messenger.

content:
Background images can be added to the message list (threads pane) and the reading pane (message pane) with css.

For the message list, add this to userChrome.css: 

/* threads pane bg image */ table[is="tree-view-table"] { background-image: url("file:///path to image") !important;}


For the message pane, add this to userContent.css: 

/* message pane bg image */ body { background-image: url("file:///path to image") !important;}


The image will tile if its width is less than the pane width. The url syntax is for Windows.

Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder (Linux:Open Directory), close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css (userContent.css), Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

video on how to create a css file (Firefox and TB)
creator: sfhowes

content:
Your sibling or Nephew was lazy and clicked reply on an email from the thread and modified it. Unfortunately that does not reset the references heading in the email, so it remains implicitly connected to the original discussion.

This is something that mostly happens with older folk that are struggling with the whole compose a new message thing, or think they are saving time by reusing an old message that is already partially addressed. Often these folk are professional people who simply can not be bothered to learn about this new fanged email thing and do strange things that someone else regularly has to sort for them. But in their view they are competent and saving time their way. (I am describing my old boss here really) and anything that messes up is the software's fault.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Have you ever used PGP encryption with Thunderbird? That icon is disabled and has a slash through it when PGP, or E2EE as it is often referred to, is simply not configured for that account.

content:
Latest update. Someone responded to a similar post I had at Gitlab. want to share it here because it may help others and though thier suggestion was helpful did not actually solve the issue. Here is a copy of my reply to that person at Gitlab:

thanks for that https://gitlab.com/CardBook/CardBook/-/issues/1602 link, it does have a link to more recent version of cardbook 93.3 than my original 92.9 with the problem. I installed it yesterday and it does help a bit, but not really a solution.

Here is the improvement: now when I click the edit button I no longer get a blank thunderbird contact folder. I still do not get a cardbook contact folder, I still get a thunderbird folder but it now has that original contact information filled it and it is editable, kinda. the difference in not having a true cardbook contact folder is that the thunderbird contact folder does not have the ability to edit the many sub categories that cardbook has available. ie. clients/current or completed or pending or other sub categories of clients, like design, build,etc. same for subcontractors and all other major categories.

I love how cardbook gives me more control and faster ways to find info because of that feature and would like to get it working.

content:
alysenet said
When I right-click an email line item sitting in my Sent folder and then select Move to > Recent > and then select a folder for it to go into, like in this case of selecting "2024 After Jacqueline" folder, *what is making the second and onward moved items become "sub" items of the first-moved item? See the screenshot attached for an example.

Messasge threading. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

I don't know if this happens in other "move" type cases; this just recently reached my radar; perhaps it's omnipresent and has been going on a while. I do recall months ago, searching feverishly for an email, and then finding it as a "sub" under another email, just like this current situation.

If you lost your profile on an undate and reentered your account information you will have been caught up in the changing of the default threading to on from off. But yes it has been around a while.

1) How would I now get that *second* line item (Socially-Responsible Investing Alyse-Style), for example, to NOT be in a sort of "folder" of the first line item (End-of-Year-Planning Questionnaire)? All I had done was, in my Sent box, I right-clicked an email, then selected Move to > Recent > 2024 Started w Jacqueline, and it ended up in the 2024 After Jacqueline as wanted, but mistakenly *within* "End-of-Year-Planning Questionnaire" line item as a sort of "sub" line item. I simply want all items that I move to the 2024 After Jacqueline folder to end up in left-hand-alignment with each other ... all line items flush left. For example, like this: End-of-Year Planning Questionnaire Socially-Responsible Investing Alyse-Style 2) How do I make that STOP happening for future email line-item moves?

I think all of that is covered in the article I linked to. Personally I would change the default and then revert my folders.
